note:
Name:  ___                  Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
Statins-Hmg-Coa Reductase Inhibitors
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
headache, hypertensive urgency
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None

 
History of Present Illness:
___ is a ___ female with PMH of Afib on 
amiodarone/apixaban, Type B dissection, CKD, HTN, 
hypothyroidism, and gastritis, who presented with headache in 
the setting of hypertensive urgency. 

The patient was recently seen in clinic on ___ for evaluation 
of headaches that had been intermittently present over the past 
several weeks located over her forehead and top of head, 
partially responsive to Tylenol. On that visit, her home HTN 
regimen was reviewed as well as her home BP recordings, which 
were in decent range of 130s/50s to 150s/60s. Her headaches were 
thought to be tension-type and she was instructed to increase 
the dose of Tylenol and try some caffeine to see if this would 
help. It was also postulated that her isosorbide may be related 
to her headaches. Reassuringly, the patient had a CT head on 
___ without concerning intracranial pathology. 

On the morning of admission, the patient's daughter took her 
blood pressure and noted SBP in the low 200s. She then had one 
episode of vomiting in the setting of a severe headache. Due to 
these symptoms, she was brought to the ED for further 
evaluation. 

In the emergency department, she was noted to be hypertensive 
again with systolic BP of 200 that resolved to 170 without 
intervention. She was subsequently given her home medications 
with further improvement of her blood pressure to within normal 
range. CT head without bleed or other concerning findings. She 
was admitted to medicine for further management of hypertensive 
urgency. 

Upon arrival to the floor, the patient was interviewed with 
assistance of daughter present at bedside. The patient reports 
she is feeling 100% better with complete resolution of her HA. 
She further denies any other red flag symptoms including change 
in vision, chest pain, shortness of breath, or lower extremity 
swelling. She additionally denies any symptoms concerning for 
GCA including no scalp tenderness, jaw fatigue with chewing, or 
any shoulder/hip soreness or weakness suggestive of PMR. Her 
daughter notes that aside from the day of admission, her home 
blood pressures have otherwise been in good range and she at 
times haves HAs while normotensive, albeit none quite as severe. 


ROS: Pertinent positives and negatives as noted in the HPI. All 
other systems were reviewed and are negative. 
 
Past Medical History:
Aortic dissection complicated by bradycardic arrests x2 
(admission of ___
Upper GI bleed ___ gastric ulcer (admission of ___
HTN 
HLD
CAD s/p NSTEMI ___
Hepatic steatosis
Carotid stenosis
Osteoporosis
CKD
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Brother, ___, RENAL CANCER                            
Brother, ___, MYOCARDIAL INFARCTION                         

Brother, ___, MYOCARDIAL INFARCTION

 
Physical Exam:
___ ___ Temp: 97.7 PO BP: 151/58 HR: 62 RR: 20 O2 sat: 98%
O2 delivery: RA 
GENERAL: pleasant older, mostly ___ speaking woman, alert 
and
in no apparent distress. 
EYES: Anicteric, pupils equally round
ENT: Ears and nose without visible erythema, masses, or trauma. 
Oropharynx without visible lesion, erythema or exudate
CV: Heart regular, no murmur, no S3, no S4.  No JVD.
RESP: Lungs clear to auscultation with good air movement
bilaterally.  Breathing is non-labored
GI: Abdomen soft, non-distended, non-tender to palpation.  Bowel
sounds present.  No HSM
GU: No suprapubic fullness or tenderness to palpation
MSK: Neck supple, moves all extremities, strength grossly full
and symmetric bilaterally in all limbs
SKIN: No rashes or ulcerations noted
NEURO: Alert, oriented, face symmetric, gaze conjugate with 
EOMI,
speech fluent, moves all limbs, sensation to light touch grossly
intact throughout
PSYCH: pleasant, appropriate affect
 
Pertinent Results:
LABS:
=====
___:45PM BLOOD WBC-4.4 RBC-3.19* Hgb-10.2* Hct-32.1* 
MCV-101* MCH-32.0 MCHC-31.8* RDW-14.6 RDWSD-52.3* Plt ___
___ 06:45PM BLOOD Glucose-102* UreaN-19 Creat-1.7* Na-139 
K-4.0 Cl-96 HCO3-27 AnGap-16
___ 08:45AM BLOOD Glucose-126* UreaN-16 Creat-1.3* Na-141 
K-4.2 Cl-100 HCO3-29 AnGap-12
___ 06:45PM BLOOD ALT-22 AST-39 AlkPhos-106* TotBili-0.4

IMAGING: 
=======
CT head ___. Streak artifact limits evaluation of pons and midbrain.
2. No acute intracranial abnormality, no definite evidence of 
acutehemorrhage.  Please note MRI of the brain is more sensitive 
for the detectionof acute infarct.
3.  Atrophy, probable small vessel ischemic changes, and 
atherosclerotic vascular disease as described.
4. Minimal paranasal sinus disease , as described.
 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ with PMH of Afib on amiodarone/apixaban, Type B dissection, 
CKD, HTN, hypothyroidism, and gastritis, who presented with 
headache in the setting of  hypertensive urgency. Fortunately, 
her BPs are now well controlled after receiving her home regimen 
and her headache has completely resolved. 

# Headache: 
# Hypertensive Urgency: 
Patient with acute on chronic severe headache with vomiting x1 
in setting of systolic BP > 200. No concern for hypertensive 
emergency given no AMS or focal neurologic changes, chest pain 
or ECG changes, ___, or signs/symptoms of CHF 
exacerbation. CT head without bleed or mass. Though patient with 
known type B dissection, repeat CTA chest not pursued as BP 
equal in both arms and patient without chest pain symptoms. 
Headache fully resolved with correction of BP to normal range. 
Patient also with history of HAs while normotensive, thus 
suspect that she is also experiencing tension-type HAs that may 
be unrelated. There is low concern for GCA given absence of 
scalp tenderness, vision change, jaw claudication, or PMR 
symptoms. Unclear why the patient became so abruptly 
hypertensive in setting of otherwise fairly decent control as 
she and her daughter report full compliance. Potential secondary 
causes of severe HTN can be explored at discretion of PCP, but 
does not require inpatient admission at this time. BP 120s/60s 
at time of discharge. 

CHRONIC/STABLE PROBLEMS:

# Atrial fibrillation: Continued amiodarone and apixiban 2.5mg 
BID 

# HFpEF: No evidence of acute exacerbation. Continued torsemide 
and home BP regimen of carvedilol, losartan, amlodipine, and 
isosorbide. 

# Type B Aortic dissection: BP symmetric in both arms. No 
symptoms to raise concern for progression. 

# CKD: Baseline Cr reported to be ~1.6. Currently 1.3 on 
discharge.

# Hypothyroidism: Continued levothyroxine 25mcg qOD

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES:
====================
[] work up for secondary causes of hypertension per PCP 
___. 

> 30 mins spent coordinating discharge

The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.

12. Apixaban 2.5 mg PO BID 
13. Amiodarone 100 mg PO DAILY 
14. Isosorbide Mononitrate (Extended Release) 90 mg PO QPM 
15. Isosorbide Dinitrate 10 mg PO ASDIR

Discharge Diagnosis:

Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___, 

It was a privilege to care for you at the ___ 
___. You were admitted with a severe headache and 
elevated blood pressure. By the time you came out of the ED, 
your symptoms had completely improved and your blood pressure 
was at a safe level. 

Please continue to take all medications as prescribed and follow 
up with all appointments as detailed below. 

We wish you the best! 

Sincerely, 
Your ___ Team  
 
Followup Instructions:
___

qafib.question: Does the note describe the patient as having permanent, paroxysmal, or persistent afib?

qprior_stroke.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having a stroke or transient ischemic attack?

qarterial_hypertension.question: Does the note describe the patient as having arterial hypertension on treatment (high bp e.g. >140, or HTN)?

qt2d.question: Does the note describe the patient as having Diabetes mellitus (DM1, DM2, T2D, T1DM, T2DM)?

qheart_failure.question: Does the note describe the patient as having heart failure?

qsurgical_valvular_disease.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having valvular disease requiring surgery (stenosis)?

qafib_ablation.question: Does the note describe the patient as having a planned or past ablation procedure for afib?

qbleeding.question: Does the note describe the patient as having a serious bleeding in the past 6 months?

qpeptic_ulcer_disease.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having peptic ulcer disease?

qrecent_stroke.question: Does the note describe the patient as having a stroke during this admission or within the last month? (Answer yes for any recent stroke if the date is unclear)

qhemorrhagic.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having any hemorrhagic tendencies or blood dyscrasias?

qbipolar.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever being diagnosed with bipolar disorder?

qschizophrenia.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever being diagnosed with schizophrenia or any schizoaffective disorders?

qmdd.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever being diagnosed with depression or major depressive disorder (MDD)?

qmed_decisions.question: Does the note describe the patient as being unable to make medical decisions? (Answer no unless there is evidence the patient cannot make their own medical decisions).

qchads2.question: What is the highest CHADS2 score mentioned? Answer "NA" if no CHADS2 score is in the note.

qblood_glucose.question: What is the highest blood glucose lab mentioned? Answer "NA" if no blood glucose score is in the note.

qlvef.question: What is the lowest left ventricular ejection (LVEF, ef, ejection fraction) fraction mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no LVEF is in the note, Answer 55 if the lowest value is 55% or greater.

qPLT.question: What is the lowest platelet count (PLT) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no platelet count is available in the note.

qHGB.question: What is the lowest hemoglobin (HGB) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no HGB value is available in the note.

qCREAT.question: What is the higest serum creatinine (Creat) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no creatinine value is available in the note.

qAST.question: What is the higest aspartate aminotransferase level (AST) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no AST value is available in the note.

qBILI.question: What is the higest total bilirubin (TotBili, Bili) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no bilirubin value is available in the note.
